stimulus:
Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task

You are about to start a new task. In this task, you will be asked to view a series of photographs and to describe what the person in the picture is thinking or feeling.

Press the space bar to continue

You will see a series of photographs of eyes. For each set of eyes, type 1, 2, 3 or 4 to choose which word best describes what the person in the picture is thinking or feeling. You may feel that more than one word is applicable but please choose just one word, the word which you consider to be most suitable. Before making your choice, make sure that you have read all 4 words. You should try to do the task as quickly as possible. If you do not know what a word means, place your mouse over it and you will see its definition.

Press the space bar to continue

1. jealous envious
Tony was jealous of all the taller, better-looking boys in his class.2. panicked distraught, feeling of terror or anxiety
On waking to find the house on fire, the whole family were panicked.
3. arrogant conceited, self-important, having a big opinion of oneself
The arrogant man thought he knew more about politics than everyone else in the room.4. hateful showing intense dislike
The two sisters were hateful to each other and always fighting.

1. indifferent disinterested, unresponsive, don’t care
Terry was completely indifferent as to whether they went to the cinema or the pub.2. embarrassed ashamed
After forgetting a colleague’s name, Jenny felt very embarrassed.
3. sceptical doubtful, suspicious, mistrusting
Patrick looked sceptical as someone read out his horoscope to him.4. dispirited glum, miserable, low
Adam was dispirited when he failed his exams.

1. decisive already made your mind up
Jane looked very decisive as she walked into the polling station.2. amused finding something funny
I was amused by a funny joke someone told me.
3. aghast horrified, astonished, alarmed
Jane was aghast when she discovered her house had been burgled.4. bored feeling weary because one is unoccupied or lacks interest in one’s current activity
I am bored today.

1. panicked distraught, feeling of terror or anxiety
On waking to find the house on fire, the whole family were panicked.2. incredulous not believing
Simon was incredulous when he heard that he had won the lottery.
3. despondent gloomy, despairing, without hope
Gary was despondent when he did not get the job he wanted.4. interested inquiring, curious
After seeing Jurassic Park, Huge grew very interested in dinosaurs.

1. ashamed overcome with shame or guilt
The boy felt ashamed when his mother discovered him stealing money from her purse.2. confident self-assured, believing in oneself
The tennis player was feeling very confident about winning his match.
3. joking being funny, playful
Gary was always joking with his friends.4. dispirited glum, miserable, low
Adam was dispirited when he failed his exams.

1. ashamed overcome with shame or guilt
The boy felt ashamed when his mother discovered him stealing money from her purse.2. nervous apprehensive, tense, worried
Just before her job interview, Alice felt very nervous.
3. suspicious disbelieving, suspecting, doubting
After Sam had lost his wallet for the second time at work, he grew suspicious of one of his colleagues.4. indecisive unsure, hesitant, unable to make your mind up
Tammy was so indecisive that she couldn’t even decide what to have for lunch.

1. puzzled perplexed, bewildered, confused
After doing the crossword for an hour, June was still puzzled by one clue.2. nervous apprehensive, tense, worried
Just before her job interview, Alice felt very nervous.
3. insisting demanding, persisting, maintaining
After a work outing, Frank was insisting he paid the bill for everyone.4. contemplative reflective, thoughtful, considering
John was in a contemplative mood on the eve of his 60th birthday.

You are about to start a new task. In this task, you will be asked to view a series of photographs and to describe what the person in the picture is thinking or feeling.

Press the space bar to continue

You will see a series of photographs of eyes. For each set of eyes, type 1, 2, 3 or 4 to choose which word best describes what the person in the picture is thinking or feeling. You may feel that more than one word is applicable but please choose just one word, the word which you consider to be most suitable. Before making your choice, make sure that you have read all 4 words. You should try to do the task as quickly as possible. If you do not know what a word means, place your mouse over it and you will see its definition.

Press the space bar to continue

1. jealous envious
Tony was jealous of all the taller, better-looking boys in his class.2. panicked distraught, feeling of terror or anxiety
On waking to find the house on fire, the whole family were panicked.
3. arrogant conceited, self-important, having a big opinion of oneself
The arrogant man thought he knew more about politics than everyone else in the room.4. hateful showing intense dislike
The two sisters were hateful to each other and always fighting.

1. ashamed overcome with shame or guilt
The boy felt ashamed when his mother discovered him stealing money from her purse.2. nervous apprehensive, tense, worried
Just before her job interview, Alice felt very nervous.
3. suspicious disbelieving, suspecting, doubting
After Sam had lost his wallet for the second time at work, he grew suspicious of one of his colleagues.4. indecisive unsure, hesitant, unable to make your mind up
Tammy was so indecisive that she couldn’t even decide what to have for lunch.

1. decisive already made your mind up
Jane looked very decisive as she walked into the polling station.2. amused finding something funny
I was amused by a funny joke someone told me.
3. aghast horrified, astonished, alarmed
Jane was aghast when she discovered her house had been burgled.4. bored feeling weary because one is unoccupied or lacks interest in one’s current activity
I am bored today.

1. panicked distraught, feeling of terror or anxiety
On waking to find the house on fire, the whole family were panicked.2. incredulous not believing
Simon was incredulous when he heard that he had won the lottery.
3. despondent gloomy, despairing, without hope
Gary was despondent when he did not get the job he wanted.4. interested inquiring, curious
After seeing Jurassic Park, Huge grew very interested in dinosaurs.

1. puzzled perplexed, bewildered, confused
After doing the crossword for an hour, June was still puzzled by one clue.2. nervous apprehensive, tense, worried
Just before her job interview, Alice felt very nervous.
3. insisting demanding, persisting, maintaining
After a work outing, Frank was insisting he paid the bill for everyone.4. contemplative reflective, thoughtful, considering
John was in a contemplative mood on the eve of his 60th birthday.

1. ashamed overcome with shame or guilt
The boy felt ashamed when his mother discovered him stealing money from her purse.2. confident self-assured, believing in oneself
The tennis player was feeling very confident about winning his match.
3. joking being funny, playful
Gary was always joking with his friends.4. dispirited glum, miserable, low
Adam was dispirited when he failed his exams.

1. indifferent disinterested, unresponsive, don’t care
Terry was completely indifferent as to whether they went to the cinema or the pub.2. embarrassed ashamed
After forgetting a colleague’s name, Jenny felt very embarrassed.
3. sceptical doubtful, suspicious, mistrusting
Patrick looked sceptical as someone read out his horoscope to him.4. dispirited glum, miserable, low
Adam was dispirited when he failed his exams.
